project_abstract.cdata: The objectives of the Third Social Fund for Development Project are: to further improve access of low income groups to basic social services, while providing an example of an effective, efficient, and transparent institutional mechanism for providing social services in Yemen by: (i) refining social service delivery approaches, and (ii) empowering local communities and councils to take charge of their local development. The project has the following three components: 1) the Social Fund for Development (SFD) will continue to support subprojects in the areas of education, water and environment, health and social protection, cultural heritage, and rural/feeder roads; with the following subcomponents: a) education; b) water and environment; c) health and social protection; d) cultural heritage; e) rural/feeder roads; 2) during the last six years, the Small and Micro Enterprise Development (SMED) unit succeeded in laying the foundation of an emerging micro finance (MF) industry. It has amongst others: (i) created awareness and understanding among policy makers on best practice; (ii) experimented with, and developed MF models that work in Yemen; and (iii) made available tools such as software and training materials to the industry as whole. The SMED unit's achievements are recognized by other donors such as United Nations Capital Development Fund (UNCDF), which have selected the team as a partner; and 3) capacity building, and institutional support: the SFD will continue to finance activities in two main areas: training, and organizational support including training on project management. The component will focus on four target groups: (i) formally established non-government organizations (NGOs) and cooperatives; (ii) informal Community-Based Organizations (CBO); (iii) private sector (individual local consultants); and (iv) local authorities (elected local councils and execu
